meaning_mnemonic: If you only let <radical>oneself</radical> (yourself) into your <radical>heart</radical>, you'll end up <kanji>mourning</kanji> all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in.
reading_mnemonic: While you're in <kanji>mourning</kanji>, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A <reading>key</reading> (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning?

meaning_mnemonic: Going from a <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's <radical>big</radical> even for yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), is a huge <kanji>transition</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You decide one <kanji>transition</kanji> isn't enough, so you transition to a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to make an <radical>exit</radical> because you're so <kanji>clumsy</kanji>. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the knob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave.
reading_mnemonic: After you make your <kanji>clumsy</kanji> mistake you realize that these doors come in <reading>sets</reading> (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors!

meaning_mnemonic: If there are <radical>mountain</radical>s <radical>above</radical> and <radical>below</radical> you, that means you're on a <kanji>mountain pass</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: It's only on this type of <kanji>mountain pass</kanji> that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable <reading>To</reading>kyo <reading>ge</reading>cko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!

meaning_mnemonic: If someone makes a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>horse</radical>, you know it's <kanji>deliberate</kanji>. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo.
reading_mnemonic: As you admire all the <kanji>deliberate</kanji> details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions."

meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>stop</radical> a <radical>turkey</radical> by putting a <radical>spoon</radical> in its face you'll know it's a <kanji>female</kanji> turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>female</kanji> turkey then runs around making a <reading>mess</reading> (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.

meaning_mnemonic: If there is <radical>dirt</radical> in a <radical>crab trap</radical>, it's a lot for the crabs to <kanji>endure</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to make the little crab that <kanji>endure</kanji>d being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a <reading>colla</reading>r (こら) round its little neck.

meaning_mnemonic: We want you to say things with your <radical>mouth</radical> right <radical>now</radical> because it's <kanji>recital</kanji> time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!
reading_mnemonic: Here, if you are too afraid to start the <kanji>recital</kanji> now drink this <reading>gin</reading> (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!

meaning_mnemonic: Making a mnemonic for a <radical>crab trap</radical> is <kanji>VERY</kanji> hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!
reading_mnemonic: You know what else is <kanji>very</kanji> something? <reading>Jean</reading>s (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>mountain</radical>'s <radical>roof</radical> are people using <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to <kanji>worship</kanji> the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others <kanji>worship</kanji> in the mountain and they're going to <reading>sue</reading> (すう) you for the noise.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>tree</radical> and your <radical>hat</radical> protects you from the <radical>water</radical>, but the hat itself is now covered in <kanji>lacquer</kanji>. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to scoop up the rest of the <kanji>lacquer</kanji> water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>mountain</radical> in the shape of a <radical>turtle shell</radical> sticking out into the ocean. It's a <kanji>cape</kanji>! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
reading_mnemonic: You decide to walk along this <kanji>cape</kanji> because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old <reading>me</reading>at <reading>sack</reading> (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).

meaning_mnemonic: Move <radical>thread</radical> in the right <radical>direction</radical> and you'll end up <kanji>spinning</kanji> it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!
reading_mnemonic: While you're <kanji>spinning</kanji> you realize that you've always wanted to make your own <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>stone</radical> that looks like a <radical>turkey</radical> <radical>boil</radical>ing underwater is just a <kanji>reef</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>reef</kanji> is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>barracks</radical> radical and the <kanji>barracks</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Barracks</kanji> are pretty big, so they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (とん). And they probably take tons of materials to build.

meaning_mnemonic: You meet a <radical>woman</radical> whose <radical>mouth</radical> is <radical>big</radical> and you instantly know this is the person you want to <kanji>marry</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>marry</kanji> this woman right away and you both go straight to an <reading>inn</reading> (いん) together!

meaning_mnemonic: You try to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cast <radical>doubt</radical> on people by using them to <kanji>imitate</kanji> each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to <kanji>imitate</kanji> is the imitation now and they have them in a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation.

meaning_mnemonic: If you see someone <radical>eye</radical>ing your <radical>womb</radical> you're probably going to be weirded out by how <kanji>friendly</kanji> they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>friendly</kanji> guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "<reading>ぼく</reading>-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>tree</radical> growing through it and it reminds you that you need more <kanji>leisure</kanji> time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>leisure</kanji>ly nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you.

meaning_mnemonic: When under<radical>ground</radical> <radical>music</radical> makes it out into the light of the <radical>sun</radical> (the public), it finally becomes <kanji>official</kanji>. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.
reading_mnemonic: Once the music is <kanji>official</kanji>, you'll feel it in your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too.

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> how <radical>eternity</radical> sounds you have to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. <kanji>Recite</kanji> those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem about an <reading>a</reading>corn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>drop</radical> to the ground in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and then <radical>drop</radical> down in front of the <radical>cross</radical> you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as <kanji>lowly</kanji> as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that.
reading_mnemonic: The only problem about being <kanji>lowly</kanji> is the <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>leader</radical> will come to <kanji>despise</kanji> their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.
reading_mnemonic: The more you <kanji>despise</kanji> them, the more <reading>boo</reading>ze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people.

meaning_mnemonic: Take <radical>three</radical> <radical>measurement</radical>s of <radical>gold</radical> and <radical>slide</radical> them into a mold to make a <kanji>cast</kanji>! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.
reading_mnemonic: You open the <kanji>cast</kanji> to reveal your gold statue of <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>net</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>slide</radical>s down like a <radical>drop</radical>. There they stay, an icon of <kanji>scorn</kanji> and <kanji>neglect</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Every time you receive <kanji>scorn</kanji> and <kanji>neglect</kanji> from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I <reading>bets</reading> (べつ) you I can get up if I want. I bets you I can."

meaning_mnemonic: If you stay up so long that you see the <radical>moon</radical> go down and the <radical>dawn</radical> come, people will say you have serious <kanji>guts</kanji>. It takes guts to stay up that late. More specifically, it takes a powerful <kanji>gallbladder</kanji>. Your gallbladder is sensitive to sleep changes, you know, so you risk a lot by staying up like that.
reading_mnemonic: You stayed awake outside for so long, just to prove you had <kanji>guts</kanji> and powerful <kanji>gallbladder</kanji>, that you also got a sweet <reading>tan</reading> (たん) out of it!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>good</radical>. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you <kanji>wander</kanji> the lands in search of it.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>wander</kanji>, you come across a clue. It is fish <reading>roe</reading> (ろう).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spirit</radical> wearing two <radical>mustache</radical>s must be <kanji>evil</kanji>. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil.
reading_mnemonic: You're watching the <kanji>evil</kanji> mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your <reading>ca</reading>r (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil!

meaning_mnemonic: You can only give a <radical>kiss</radical> of <radical>alcohol</radical> to <kanji>dairy</kanji>. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Dairy</kanji> isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a <reading>rack</reading> (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!

meaning_mnemonic: If a pilot manages to land under a <radical>canopy</radical> with a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's pierced with a sideways <radical>barb</radical> in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> you should <kanji>congratulate</kanji> them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Congratulate</kanji> the pilot with <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)!

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>Asia</kanji>. 

This can also mean <kanji>sub-</kanji>. As in subtropics, subspecies, subhuman… That kind of sub-! When it's not in a place name, 亜 will usually be using its sub- meaning.
reading_mnemonic: What's the first sound in <kanji>Asia</kanji>? It's <reading>A</reading> (あ). Nice and easy!

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>tsunami</radical> that's heading for your village is <radical>fat</radical> you should try to <kanji>select</kanji> a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.
reading_mnemonic: If you're having trouble <kanji>select</kanji>ing which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating <reading>ta</reading>cos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.

meaning_mnemonic: What kind of <radical>tree</radical> is <radical>spicy</radical>? A <kanji>Japanese birch</kanji>, or <kanji>birch</kanji>, obviously. There's nothing spicier than a Japanese birch!
reading_mnemonic: You can only cut down a <kanji>Japanese birch</kanji> using <reading>a zoo saw</reading> (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these trees are.

meaning_mnemonic: People think <radical>tsunami</radical>s are only made of water but they have a <radical>few</radical> pieces of <kanji>sand</kanji> in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.
reading_mnemonic: You already learnt the reading for 砂, the other kanji for <kanji>sand</kanji>. It should be easy to remember this one too, since it's also さ!
